commit_message:
Don't do unnecessary updates in ResourceGroup rolling updates

During a rolling update of a ResourceGroup, there may be extra resources
around (due to a simultaneous scale-down) that contribute to our
min_in_service but which are fated to be deleted. There is no point
updating these. This patch changes to algorithm to only update resources we
actually care about. (Happily, this makes the logic a lot simpler too.)

Change-Id: I4eedccfb0ca3b6d6eab3a777635836c39cda76cd
Partially-Implements: blueprint scaling-group-common
Closes-Bug: #1489192

commit_message:
Cannot deploy by tag if groups are distributed among hosts

If we run ansible to deploy particular role by tag some tasks
fail because ansible does not gather facts from other hosts.
E.g. haproxy on [network] won't be able to find ip addresses
of [controller] services. This fix forces gathering facts from all
hosts despite on tags.

Change-Id: Ibb630353049183c263972203205c3b449b1b1763
Closes-Bug: #1482406

commit_message:
Correct name of source archive if reference contains '/'

If we have reference like stable/kilo name of source archive
will contain only last part of reference. We should replace '/'
with '-' to have full name. This is useful for correct
identification of source code afterwards.

Change-Id: I1ff1015e3f7926110d0fcb59504e58a5e80a75f9
Closes-Bug: #1492279

commit_message:
Refactoring to make Websocket driver available in v2

Considering that most of this feature landed during the Liberty
cycle, it made sense to make Websocket a v2 feature.

APIImpact
Implements-blueprint: persistent-transport
Change-Id: I52ef38f32afd688239d4aee9ac379cd8dea03d6c

commit_message:
Sync devstack plugin with devstack:lib/ceilometer

This removes the cp of the meters.yaml file to /etc/ceilometer. It
is not needed.

This is part of a regular process of keeping the plugin and the
devstack version functionally equivalent until the devstack version
finally goes away.

Change-Id: I1261f054f077b73d3d64529ca9c59678ecbf15de

commit_message:
Return 400 status for invalid network config

NetworkCheck class is decoupled from tasks, now it just raises errors,
which are handled in task.
Task message, status and progress are set according to the result of
config validation.
Tests are adjusted.

Change-Id: Icc92409e84037d65e9a275191b9c9881bcffe2c9
Closes-Bug: #1469331

The stack-create operation fails.  This WIP makes it work, but I
am uncertain if this fix is the correct solution.  What should happen
is there should be a [trustee] section which is used to set the
correct parameters.  Putting only admin_user and admin_password
in the trustee section doesn't get it going.  Reading through the
code now to determine what should be in this [trustee] section.  From
what I can tell it just overrides the keystone auth token credentials
during domain operations.

Change-Id: I06dd6436cc34a37b4966fddc888fade982ea51bd
Closes-Bug: 1492648

commit_message:
Make heat stack-create work

The stack-create operation fails.  The current implementation of
Heat Ansible role does not implement trusts.  Tell heat it should use
the non-trusts authentication model.

Also add a [keystone_clients] section which is required in newer
versions of heat to properly resolve the keystone v3 API endpoint
required for trust communication.

This fix spawns a Tech-Debt Bug to implement trusts in heat: #1492736

Change-Id: I06dd6436cc34a37b4966fddc888fade982ea51bd
Closes-Bug: #1492648

Make package change run the db_sync

run on upgrade.

commit_message:
Ignore vim swap files

commit_message:
Merge the two weak_cryptographic_key checks

We don't need two separate checks:
    weak_crypto_key_size_cryptography_io
    weak_crypto_key_size_pycrypto

This patch combines them into a single check:
    weak_cryptographic_key

Change-Id: I9626341a6f00a52fcc0eb11621c261fbc3f656e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bandit refs/changes/94/220594/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Clean the re-implemented serializers in Heat

The RequestContextSerializer and JsonPayloadSerializer have been
implemented in oslo_messaging, This change remove the re-implemented
serializers in heat/common/messaging.py

Change-Id: Ie659bff587631da5875a9e5de7d051e430e8939f

added_lines: from oslo_messaging import serializer as oslo_serializer serializer = oslo_serializer.RequestContextSerializer( oslo_serializer.JsonPayloadSerializer()) serializer = oslo_serializer.RequestContextSerializer( oslo_serializer.JsonPayloadSerializer()) serializer = oslo_serializer.RequestContextSerializer( oslo_serializer.JsonPayloadSerializer())
deleted_lines: from oslo_serialization import jsonutils from osprofiler import profiler from heat.common import context class RequestContextSerializer(oslo_messaging.Serializer): def __init__(self, base): self._base = base def serialize_entity(self, ctxt, entity): if not self._base: return entity return self._base.serialize_entity(ctxt, entity) def deserialize_entity(self, ctxt, entity): if not self._base: return entity return self._base.deserialize_entity(ctxt, entity) @staticmethod def serialize_context(ctxt): _context = ctxt.to_dict() prof = profiler.get() if prof: trace_info = { "hmac_key": prof.hmac_key, "base_id": prof.get_base_id(), "parent_id": prof.get_id() } _context.update({"trace_info": trace_info}) return _context @staticmethod def deserialize_context(ctxt): trace_info = ctxt.pop("trace_info", None) if trace_info: profiler.init(**trace_info) return context.RequestContext.from_dict(ctxt) class JsonPayloadSerializer(oslo_messaging.NoOpSerializer): @classmethod def serialize_entity(cls, context, entity): return jsonutils.to_primitive(entity, convert_instances=True) serializer = RequestContextSerializer(JsonPayloadSerializer()) serializer = RequestContextSerializer(JsonPayloadSerializer()) serializer = RequestContextSerializer(JsonPayloadSerializer())

commit_message:
Fix a unit test for create instance

The test_launch_form_keystone_exception test method calls the
handle method of the LaunchInstance class. Changes made to
the handle method in [1] introduced a new neutron api call
that was not being mocked out, causing an unexpected exception
in the _cleanup_ports_on_failed_vm_launch function of the
create_instance module, while running the
test_launch_form_keystone_exception unit test

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/202347/

Closes-Bug: 1492065
Change-Id: Ib3ad9146339a60b8d53e849091abf6a9bb64de93

Migrate volume tests to the ssh-auth-strategy

Migrate the volume tests to the new ssh-auth-strategy format. In this case, it
is just using the common test_create_server.

Partially implements: blueprint ssh-auth-strategy

commit_message:
Prevent volume already in CG to be added to another

If a volume is already in a CG, currently it can still be added to
another CG without any warning. We should add a check to see if the
volume is already in a CG and prevent it from being added to another
if that check returns True. It has to be removed from the previous
CG in order to be added to a new one.

Change-Id: I6ec92cbf4ce60e7afbfa5a57edef18ddba554a74
Closes-Bug: #1487151

commit_message:
[spec] Consistent resource names

Name resources consistently to improve cleanup and make Rally more
generic.

Change-Id: I2888b9874c695a6616576c22f3ea218901911b5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/45/201545/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================= Consistent Resource Names ========================= To facilitate better cleanup of ephemeral resources created by Rally, our resource names need to be consistent across all scenarios and all plugins. Additionally, to support Rally's use against systems other than OpenStack, the list of characters used in generating resource names should be configurable. Problem description =================== Currently we use a few different cleanup mechanisms, some of which (Keystone) use resource names, while most others use tenant membership. As a result, if Rally is interrupted before cleanup completes it may not be possible to know which resources were created by Rally (and thus should be cleaned up after the fact). Random names are generated from a fairly limited set of digits and ASCII letters. This should be configurable, along with all other parts of the random name, in order to support benchmarking systems other than OpenStack, which may have different naming restrictions. Finally, each Rally task should include some consistent element in its resource names, distinct from other Rally tasks, to support multiple independent Rally runs and cleanup. Proposed change =============== All resources created by Rally will have the same name prefix. Following the name prefix, there will be two random elements: one that will be the same for all resources created by a task, and one that will be unique for all resources. These will be configured by three settings in `rally.conf`:: resource_name_format = rally_XXXXXXXX_XXXXXXXX context_resource_name_format = rally_ctx_XXXXXXXX_XXXXXXXX resource_name_allowed_characters = ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789 `resource_name_format` is for resources created by Rally scenarios; `context_resource_name_format` is for resources created by contexts. These have different name formats because they have different cleanup requirements. Both accept `mktemp(1)`-style strings. Several constraints will be imposed upon these options: * Both format options must have two separate sets of at least three consecutive 'X's. (That is, they must match: `^.*(?<!X)X{3,}(?!X).*(?<!X)X{3,}(?!X)`. This marks a slight departure from `mktemp(1)`, which requires a single set of three or more 'X's at the end.) * The two format options must be different. We will attempt to use the task ID, stripped of dashes, for the first random portion. If `resource_name_allowed_characters` does not allow all of the characters in the task ID (lowercase letters and digits), then we will randomly generate the first portion from `resource_name_allowed_characters`. The second random portion will be generated randomly. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stpierre aka Chris St. Pierre Other contributors: rvasilets aka Roman Vasilets wtakase aka Wataru Takase Work Items ---------- * Overhaul `rally.common.utils.generate_random_name()` and `rally.task.scenarios.base.Scenario._generate_random_name()`. Early proof of concept that implements some of the points in this spec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/184888/ * Find and fix resources that are created without generate_random_name(). Dependencies ============ None.

commit_message:
trap another source of fatal errors

The jenkins check was dying sometimes, causing the entire script to
abort instead of allowing a retry.

Also quiet the warnings from urllib3 about not having certificates set
up.

Change-Id: I013d30478cda6b5e56ba3fe1381f6628b38501a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/84/220284/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: job_json = get_from_jenkins(job_url) if not job_json['building']: return job_json['artifacts'][-1]['displayPath']

commit_message:
Revert "Decentralize the managemement of service providers"

This reverts commit 61121c5f2af27e31092db7ac6947f796198410a8.

The patch broke service config loading, and affected puppet-neutron CI.

commit_message:
Make update_server use **kwargs

As we discussed on
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-July/068864.html
All http POST/PUT methods need to contain **kwargs as their arguments.
This patch makes update_server use **kwargs.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: Iac517acbd80d8140461b3e8853573add1ab4a9eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/59/217459/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def update_server(self, server_id, **kwargs): """Updates the properties of an existing server. Most parameters except the following are passed to the API without any changes. :param disk_config: The name is changed to OS-DCF:diskConfig if kwargs.get('disk_config'): kwargs['OS-DCF:diskConfig'] = kwargs.pop('disk_config') post_body = json.dumps({'server': kwargs})
deleted_lines: def update_server(self, server_id, name=None, meta=None, accessIPv4=None, accessIPv6=None, disk_config=None): Updates the properties of an existing server. server_id: The id of an existing server. name: The name of the server. personality: A list of files to be injected into the server. accessIPv4: The IPv4 access address for the server. accessIPv6: The IPv6 access address for the server. """ post_body = {} if meta is not None: post_body['metadata'] = meta if name is not None: post_body['name'] = name if accessIPv4 is not None: post_body['accessIPv4'] = accessIPv4 if accessIPv6 is not None: post_body['accessIPv6'] = accessIPv6 if disk_config is not None: post_body['OS-DCF:diskConfig'] = disk_config post_body = json.dumps({'server': post_body})

commit_message:
Return the correct size for the ResourceGroup from _get_batches()

Currently the size of the group is ignored (we do a single resize at the
end of the rolling update), but this changes _get_batches() to return the
correct value for it so we can make use of it in future.

Change-Id: Ie875ca06eb440d9bdfc80e9d52a0e3f9306e5d1b
Partially-Implements: blueprint scaling-group-common

commit_message:
Calculate ResourceGroup batch sizes using scaling library

Use the new rolling_update.next_batch() library function to calculate batch
sizes for ResourceGroup rolling updates, so that all scaling groups now
share a common implementation.

Change-Id: I96ff4d76c850ba5d886ca55c7983b6c87fe57b1d
Partially-Implements: blueprint scaling-group-common

commit_message:
Refactor ResourceGroup batched updates and add tests

Separate the batching logic from the code that generates the tasks to be
performed so that it can be tested separately.

commit_message:
Update logic to detect DVR in rescheduling test

The previous logic to determine of DVR was enabled
was based on checking a config variable that would
always return False.

This patch corrects it by checking for the distributed
flag on the router using the admin credentials.

Closes-Bug: #1489929
Change-Id: I47ee7bdfeb5aa3583c56e336de5a683bb1f48cf7

commit_message:
Fixed issue with rabbit_hosts parameter

We should initialize rabbit_hosts parameter with array,
not with string or boolen value.

Change-Id: Iab51d77c35fb78f70060115e0ca48238f6f9de50
Closes-Bug: #1470054

commit_message:
Use US spelling for 'behavior', instead of 'behaviour'

This change corrects all occurrences of 'behaviour', in core Neutron
comments or docstrings.

Change-Id: I3bb205929bba739c33a5c4e1642bb25233128975

subject: Share Migration support in generic driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-04 14:18:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/0a8a842070121b57266d686a81919a6ac1df27e7', 'message': '[WIP] Share Migration support in generic driver

Added minimal Share Migration support to generic driver, so the generic
migration procedure can work.

At this moment it supports:
- NFS protocol.
- Both driver modes.

The approach to support is to add a field to Share Server backend_details
named service_ip with the port IP address that allows the controller to access
the Share Servers (same IP address which they SSH through), this IP is used to
return the access rule required for the generic migration procedure.

For "driver_handles_share_servers=False" mode, it is mandatory to specify
that IP address in the config option "vm_service_ip". Please note that the
IP may be different depending on which network the Manual Share Server is
and how the controller connects to it.

Not implemented at this time:
- CIFS and other protocols support.
- _prepare_share method (Change migrating share to read-only).
- Optimized migration for Generic Driver.

Change-Id: Ie7d19a44c9ab05c5a6a79c30478be23b2e8a3ba2

'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2015-06-16 12:45:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/74b1a9b1a14cff1b5b358ec539c46a11acfd95ae', 'message': '[WIP] Share Migration support in generic driver

Added minimal Share Migration support to generic driver, so the generic
migration procedure can work.

At this moment it supports:
- NFS protocol.
- Both driver modes.

The approach to support is to add a field to Share Server backend_details
named service_ip with the port IP address that allows the controller to access
the Share Servers (same IP address which they SSH through), this IP is used to
return the access rule required for the generic migration procedure.

For "driver_handles_share_servers=False" mode, it is mandatory to specify
that IP address in the config option "vm_service_ip". Please note that the
IP may be different depending on which network the Manual Share Server is
and how the controller connects to it.

Not implemented at this time:
- CIFS and other protocols support.
- _prepare_share method (Change migrating share to read-only).
- Optimized migration for Generic Driver.

Change-Id: Ie7d19a44c9ab05c5a6a79c30478be23b2e8a3ba2

commit_message:
Share Migration support in generic driver

Added minimal Share Migration support to generic driver,
so the Generic Migration procedure can work.

The approach to support is to add a field to Share Server
backend_details named service_ip with the port IP address that
allows the controller to access the Share Servers (same IP address
which they SSH through), this IP is used to return the access rule
required for the generic migration procedure.

For "driver_handles_share_servers=False" mode, configuration falls
back to common implementation in Core code and its parameters.

Optimized migration for Generic Driver will be included
as a separate patch.

Change-Id: Ie7d19a44c9ab05c5a6a79c30478be23b2e8a3ba2
Implements: blueprint share-migration
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/91/179791/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.StrOpt('vm_service_ip', default=None, help="IP address for Manila node accessing the VM in " "'driver_handles_share_server = false' mode.") self.configuration, self.driver_handles_share_servers) def _get_access_for_service_port(self, context, share, share_server): return self._get_helper(share).get_service_access_rule( context, share, share_server) def _mount_share(self, context, share, share_server): return self._get_helper(share).mount_share( context, share, share_server) def _prepare_share(self, context, share, share_server): self._get_helper(share).prepare_share(context, share, share_server) # TODO: Fix this with private share data implementation # PS: below code will not work after rebase, # now private share data is needed to fix it, # if deciding to use same volume name, must be careful # on ambiguous volumes # PS: (old code saved for later) # Workaround, should not access DB, must fix volume name accordingly # share_ref = self.db.share_get(context, share_id) # if share_ref.get('export_location'): # subject: Add support for PluginWorker and Process creation notification
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-08 18:22:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/99b6aab1bfe7bee9f7c32edf05a79cf1bd0fa186', 'message': 'Add support for post_fork plugin initialization

There are several cases where plugin initialization should be
handled after neutron-server forks API/RPC workers. For example,
starting a client connection to an SDN controller before forking
copies the fd of the socket to the child process, but then you have
multiple processes trying to read/write the same socket connection.
Also, if the plugin spawns a thread pre-fork in initialize(), the
thread does not exist in child processes which can cause deadlocks.

This patch adds support for an optional post_fork_callback plugin
method and implements passing that through to ML2 mechanism drivers.
It handles the case were api_workers==rpc_workers==0 and there is
only one process, in addition to other combinations of values for
the two config options.

The networking-ovn project is one example of a plugin which is
completely broken for api/rpc_workers != 0 since it maintains a
connection to the OVSDB server on the plugin side with no agent.

Closes-Bug: #1463129
Change-Id: Ib99954678c2b4f32f486b537979d446aafbea07b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-16 16:22:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/bed52b0b7972f482f17bf8e4ad24ee8810c89299', 'message': "Add support for PluginWorker and Process creation notification

There are several cases where plugin initialization should be
handled after neutron-server forks API/RPC workers. For example,
starting a client connection to an SDN controller before forking
copies the fd of the socket to the child process, but then you have
multiple processes trying to read/write the same socket connection.

It is also useful for a plugin to be able to do something in only
one process, regardless of how many workers are forked. One example
would be handling syncing from an external system to the neutron
database.

This patch does 3 things:
1) Treats api/rpc_workers=0 as =1. This simplifies the code for
   handling notification that forking has completed. In the
   existing code, calling the notification in the Worker object's
   start() method would happen twice in the case where both api
   and rpc workers were 0, despite there being only one process.
2) Adds notification of forking via the callbacks mechanism.
   Plugins cans subscribe to resources.PROCESS, event.AFTER_CREATE
   and do any post-fork initialization that needs to be done for
   every spawned process.
3) Adds core/service plugin calls to get_processes() which defaults
   to returning (). Plugins that need additional processes to spawn
   should just return an iterable of functions that will be spawned
   in there own process.

Closes-Bug: #1463129
Change-Id: Ib99954678c2b4f32f486b537979d446aafbea07b

commit_message:
Add support for PluginWorker and Process creation notification

There are several cases where plugin initialization should be
handled after neutron-server forks API/RPC workers. For example,
starting a client connection to an SDN controller before forking
copies the fd of the socket to the child process, but then you have
multiple processes trying to read/write the same socket connection.

It is also useful for a plugin to be able to do something in only
one process, regardless of how many workers are forked. One example
would be handling syncing from an external system to the neutron
database.

This patch does 3 things:
1) Treats rpc_workers=0 as = 1. This simplifies the code for
   handling notification that forking has completed. In the
   existing code, calling the notification in the Worker object's
   start() method would happen twice in the case where both api
   and rpc workers were 0, despite there being only one process.
   An earlier patch already changed the default api_workers to be
   the number of processors.
2) Adds notification of forking via the callbacks mechanism.
   Plugins can subscribe to resources.PROCESS, event.AFTER_CREATE
   and do any post-fork initialization that needs to be done for
   every spawned process.
3) Adds core/service plugin calls to get_workers() which defaults
   to returning (). Plugins that need additional processes to spawn
   should just return an iterable of NeutronWorkers that will be
   spawned in their own process.

DocImpact

Closes-Bug: #1463129
Change-Id: Ib99954678c2b4f32f486b537979d446aafbea07b

commit_message:
Add more concept info about live migration downtime calculation

Adds conceptual information around the downtime config parameters. The
parameters themselves have already been added in a previous patch.

Change-Id: I55c3da9892e396d1e6e90450ec9b9c6ce7d6b9f9
Closes-Bug: 1483566
Closes-Bug: 1483568
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/69/220869/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **Notes** - Because the Compute service does not use the libvirt live migration functionality by default, guests are suspended before migration and might experience several minutes of downtime. For details, see :ref:`Enabling True Live Migration`. - Compute calculates the amount of downtime required using the RAM size of the disk being migrated, in accordance with the ``live_migration_downtime`` configuration parameters. Migration downtime is measured in steps, with an exponential backoff between each step. This means that the maximum downtime between each step starts off small, and is increased in ever larger amounts as Compute waits for the migration to complete. This gives the guest a chance to complete the migration successfully, with a minimum amount of downtime. - This guide assumes the default value for ``instances_path`` in your :file:`nova.conf` file (:file:`NOVA-INST-DIR/instances`). If you have changed the ``state_path`` or ``instances_path`` variables, modify the commands accordingly. - You must specify ``vncserver_listen=0.0.0.0`` or live migration will not work correctly. - You must specify the ``instances_path`` in each node that runs nova-compute. The mount point for ``instances_path`` must be the same value for each node, or live migration will not work correctly.
deleted_lines: .. note:: - Because the Compute service does not use the libvirt live migration functionality by default, guests are suspended before migration and might experience several minutes of downtime. For details, see :ref:Enabling True Live Migration. - This guide assumes the default value for ``instances_path`` in your :file:`nova.conf` file (:file:`NOVA-INST-DIR/instances`). If you have changed the ``state_path`` or ``instances_path`` variables, modify the commands accordingly. - You must specify ``vncserver_listen=0.0.0.0`` or live migration will not work correctly. - You must specify the ``instances_path`` in each node that runs nova-compute. The mount point for ``instances_path`` must be the same value for each node, or live migration will not work correctly.

commit_message:
Added extra libvirt live migration config parameters

Three live migration config params were added to nova.conf to manage downtime
while performing live migrations. This patch adds these to the libvirt
live migration section. Another patch forthcoming to include more conceptual
information about this topic elsewhere in the book.

Change-Id: I99db413e321aaef092bbe10cb59b6084909f0c1c
Partial-Bug: 1483566
Partial-Bug: 1483568

added_lines: #. Configure the downtime required for the migration by adjusting these parameters in the :file:`nova.conf` file: .. code:: ini live_migration_downtime live_migration_downtime_steps live_migration_downtime_delay The ``live_migration_downtime`` parameter sets the maximum permitted downtime for a live migration, in milliseconds. This setting defaults to 500 milliseconds. The ``live_migration_downtime_steps`` parameter sets the total number of incremental steps to reach the maximum downtime value. This setting defaults to 10 steps. The ``live_migration_downtime_delay`` parameter sets the amount of time to wait between each step, in seconds. This setting defaults to 75 seconds. #. You can now configure other options for live migration. In most cases, you

subject: Add Share Migration feature
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-04 14:18:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/700c1f9161b22e8f585aa27f8d8c989e0a7cf104', 'message': '[WIP] Add Share Migration support

Share Migration allows a share to be migrated from one host to another host
through the "manila migrate <share> <host>" command. It first calls the driver
to perform it in an optimized way if possible. If the driver returns that it
did not migrate, it performs a generic migration.

- A new field has been added to "shares" table: migration_status.
- For generic migration, every driver needs to implement certain methods:
 - _prepare_share: change migrating share to read-only.
 - _mount_share: return the mount command.
 - _umount_share: return the umount command.
 - _get_access_for_service_port: return an access rule with the IP address
which will allow the controller to mount the share after added through
allow-access API command.
- For driver migration, the method migrate_share in driver base class
should be overriden.

Please note that this is currently a prototype
for discussion at 2015.1 Summit.

Change-Id: I8dde892cb7c0180b2b56d8c7d680dfe2320c2ec7
Implements: blueprint share-migration
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-06 13:31:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/8e6e91ac0bc60e6cb18d2dcdd75c08acaf9f8ef4', 'message': '[WIP] Add Share Migration support

Share Migration allows a share to be migrated from one host to another host
through the "manila migrate <share> <host>" command. It first calls the driver
to perform it in an optimized way if possible. If the driver returns that it
did not migrate, it performs a generic migration.

- A new field has been added to "shares" table: migration_status.
- For generic migration, every driver needs to implement certain methods:
 - _prepare_share: change migrating share to read-only.
 - _mount_share: return the mount command.
 - _umount_share: return the umount command.
 - _get_access_for_service_port: return an access rule with the IP address

for discussion at 2015.1 Summit.

Share Migration allows a share to be migrated from one host to another host
through the "manila migrate <share> <host>" command. It first calls the driver
to perform it in an optimized way if possible. If the driver returns that it
did not migrate, it performs a generic migration.

- A new field has been added to "shares" table: migration_status.
- For generic migration, every driver needs to implement certain methods:
 - _prepare_share: change migrating share to read-only.
 - _mount_share: return the mount command.
 - _umount_share: return the umount command.
 - _get_access_for_service_port: return an access rule with the IP address
which will allow the controller to mount the share after added through
allow-access API command.
- For driver migration, the method migrate_share in driver base class
should be overriden.

'}, {'number': 21, 'created': '2015-08-06 13:35:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/adaf6b408a1a5d504fa6982736276772fb4886fd', 'message': 'Add Share Migration feature

Share Migration allows a share to be migrated from one host#pool to another
host#pool through the "manila migrate <share> <host#pool>" command. It first
calls the driver to perform it in an optimized way if possible. If the driver
returns that it did not migrate, it performs a generic migration.
- A new field has been added to "shares" table: task_state, which tracks
migration status.
- For generic migration, every driver needs to implement certain methods:
- _prepare_share: change migrating share to read-only.
- _mount_share: return the mount command.
- _umount_share: return the umount command.
- _get_access_for_service_port: return an access rule with the IP address
which will allow the manila node to mount the share after added permission
through allow-access API command.
- For driver migration, the method migrate_share in driver base class
should be overriden.

Change-Id: I8dde892cb7c0180b2b56d8c7d680dfe2320c2ec7
Implements: blueprint share-migration
'}, {'number': 22, 'created': '2015-08-21 19:21:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/94e55c7a711de60b225ffd39b96339b242cf2193', 'message': 'Add Share Migration feature

Share Migration allows a share to be migrated from
one host#pool to another host#pool through the
"manila migrate <share> <host#pool>" command. It first
calls the driver to perform it in an optimized way if
possible. If the driver returns that it did not migrate,
it performs a generic migration.

A new field has been added to "shares" table: task_state,
which tracks migration status.

For driver migration, the method migrate_share in driver
base class should be overridden.

For generic migration, drivers may use new config options
to achieve the necessary configuration:
- migration_mounting_backend_ip: If backend has additional
exports IP for admin network, specify it here.
- migration_data_copy_node_ip: IP of entity performing
migration between backends, such as manila node or
data copy service node. This may not apply for
DHSS = true drivers.
- migration_protocol_mount_command: specify mount command
with protocol and additional parameters. Advisable to restrict
protocols per backend. Defaults to "mount -t <share_proto>".

If additional customization is needed, drivers may override
certain methods:
- _mount_share: return the mount command.
- _umount_share: return the umount command.
- _get_access_for_service_port: return an access rule with
the IP address which will allow the manila node to mount the
share after added permission through allow-access API command.

Change-Id: I8dde892cb7c0180b2b56d8c7d680dfe2320c2ec7
Implements: blueprint share-migration
'}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2015-08-24 12:47:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/12e2bade2e3edd9ef52f19a0ef41d11f658665f1', 'message': 'Add Share Migration feature

Share Migration allows a share to be migrated from
one host#pool to another host#pool through the
"manila migrate <share> <host#pool>" command. It first
calls the driver to perform it in an optimized way if
possible. If the driver returns that it did not migrate,
it performs a generic migration.

A new field has been added to "shares" table: task_state,
which tracks migration status.

For driver migration, the method migrate_share in driver
base class should be overridden.

For generic migration, drivers may use new config options
to achieve the necessary configuration:
- migration_mounting_backend_ip: If backend has additional
exports IP for admin network, specify it here.
- migration_data_copy_node_ip: IP of entity performing
migration between backends, such as manila node or
data copy service node. This may not apply for
DHSS = true drivers.
- migration_protocol_mount_command: specify mount command
with protocol and additional parameters. Advisable to restrict
protocols per backend. Defaults to "mount -t <share_proto>".

If additional customization is needed, drivers may override
certain methods:
- _mount_share: return the mount command.
- _umount_share: return the umount command.
- _get_access_for_service_port: return an access rule with
the IP address which will allow the manila node to mount the
share after added permission through allow-access API command.

Change-Id: I8dde892cb7c0180b2b56d8c7d680dfe2320c2ec7
Implements: blueprint share-migration

commit_message:
Add Share Migration feature

Share Migration allows a share to be migrated from
one host#pool to another host#pool through the
"manila migrate <share> <host#pool>" command. It first
calls the driver to perform it in an optimized way if
possible. If the driver returns that it did not migrate,
it performs a generic migration.

A new field has been added to "shares" table: task_state,
which tracks migration status.

For driver migration, the method migrate_share in driver
base class should be overridden.

For generic migration, drivers may use new config options
to achieve the necessary configuration:
- migration_mounting_backend_ip: If backend has additional
exports IP for admin network, specify it here.
- migration_data_copy_node_ip: IP of entity performing
migration between backends, such as manila node or
data copy service node. This may not apply for
DHSS = true drivers.
- migration_protocol_mount_command: specify mount command
with protocol and additional parameters. Advisable to restrict
protocols per backend. Defaults to "mount -t <share_proto>".

If additional customization is needed, drivers may override
certain methods:
- _mount_share: return the mount command.
- _umount_share: return the umount command.
- _get_access_rule_for_data_copy: return an access rule with
the IP address which will allow the manila node or data copy node
to mount the share after added permission through
allow-access API command.

Change-Id: I8dde892cb7c0180b2b56d8c7d680dfe2320c2ec7
Implements: blueprint share-migration

commit_message:
jenkins/scripts/copy_puppet_logs: tempest.log support

If tempest.log file is here (generated by puppet-openstack-integration),
we will archive it in logdir beside other logs.

Change-Id: Id1813c83e5c8d6d2ab8d562082d038825788e95b

commit_message:
Implement external physical bridge mapping in linuxbridge

In some deployment scenario, it is not allowed to remove system
ethernet configuration from physical interface to newly-created
physical bridge by neutron due to some IT regulations.
End-users require to take advantage of the pre-existed(user-defined)
physical bridge to connect tap devices for neutron.

Closes-Bug: #1105488
Implements: blueprint phy-net-bridge-mapping
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ia0eaa6233d8da93da32e86404b15184b77937d0a

commit_message:
Start scaling down in an InstanceGroup rolling update ASAP

When the effective batch size is reduced due to a dwindling number of
resources we need to update, we may be able to reduce the size of the group
prior to the final batch without violating the minimum number of members we
are required to keep in service. This change ensures that any excess nodes
are removed as soon as possible.

Change-Id: Ic7b9544825a92b8720dcff15fe581038dff43582
Partially-Implements: blueprint scaling-group-common

commit_message:
Avoid DB errors when deleting network's ports and subnets

DB errors may occur when accessing query results
after the transaction was closed (like ObjectDeletedError).
Hence it's better to avoid DB object access especially
when it's not needed.
This patch changes _delete_ports() and _delete_subnets() to accept
only ids. Indeed, there is no need to pass db objects to these methods.

Closes-Bug: #1484135
Related-Bug: #1454408
Change-Id: I7507cb1c85defb2e6d5144e5832aea713d6251ae

deleted_lines: try: self.delete_port(context, port.id) LOG.info(_LI("Port %s was deleted concurrently"), port.id) port.id) try: self.delete_subnet(context, subnet.id) subnet.id) subnet.id)

commit_message:
Port password tests to Python 3

* load_template_source(): use io.open() with an encoding instead of
  open(), to have the same behaviour on Python 2 and Python 3
* assertRedirectsNoFollow(): remove an useless assertion on the
  response status code which is already tested a few lines below. The
  assertion used code/100 which returns a float on Python 3, whereas
  an int was expected.
* add_logout_reason(): don't encode reason to UTF-8 on Python 3
* tox.ini: add openstack_dashboard.dashboards.settings.password to
  Python 3.4

Partial-Implements: blueprint porting-python3
Change-Id: Iff8997917b5d812952150b2abe89ddd12deab0c0

commit_message:
Correct the keyword defences to defenses

The keyword defences is inadvisable.
It's better to be modified as defenses.
Even though the meaning of defences is same as defenses,
but if be defenses the whole terms in this section are
unified as defense or defenses. And it can coincide
with the section title "Layered defenses" more.

Change-Id: Id3a0b27dd5ce1c789638f83eebba76f62eefcede
Closes-Bug: #1491036

commit_message:
Fix DeprecationWarning when using BaseException.message

Some of the nova unit tests are getting:
"DeprecationWarning: BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6 "
when referring to the message attribute of the exception.
Change to use "six.text_type(exception)" to avoid these warning.

Change-Id: I6f2c83a66306cdaccb95a7be21214f15969b6947
Closes-Bug: 1479066

commit_message:
Do not remove network from dhcp agent if they are not supported

dhcp_agent_scheduler is optional extension in Neutron which means
that we need to check whatever is supported or not before trying
to cleanup it.

closes-bug: #1491196

Change-Id: I1f7068de9dfd8ea8185206469fdc048c55a54cfc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/26/219526/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.supports_extension("dhcp_agent_scheduler"): net_dhcps = self.client.list_dhcp_agent_hosting_networks( network["id"])["agents"] for net_dhcp in net_dhcps: self.client.remove_network_from_dhcp_agent(net_dhcp["id"], network["id"])
deleted_lines: net_dhcps = self.client.list_dhcp_agent_hosting_networks( network["id"])["agents"] for net_dhcp in net_dhcps: self.client.remove_network_from_dhcp_agent(net_dhcp["id"], network["id"])

subject: Use security group id for neutron launch instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-13 02:19:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/6214817b034948ac400940f8c9fcb50a6e4278bf', 'message': 'Use security group id for launch instance

commit_message:
Use security group id for neutron launch instance

When there are two security groups with the same name, it would
not be possible to launch instance with security group name using
neutron.

Change-Id: I65c39eb728916010f0057440d856cd00f59763d9
Closes-bug: #1484750

commit_message:
Add HTTP30X checks for validate_response()

We are trying to add "get API version" test for Nova API on Temepst
side, but validate_response() doesn't work at all for the API because
the API returns HTTP300.
This patch makes validate_response() work for HTTP30X for the test.

Change-Id: If2ce6c9c9e2fde554b4e44dc99ec70d087c3f682

commit_message:
VMware: pass network info to config drive.

With same reason of race bug 1249065, the nw_info cache of
instance may be missed sometimes, in this case, the IP address
will not get injected if using config drive. This change will
pass the network info data to metadata api directly, so the
missing of nw_info cache will not block vmware instances deploy.

Change-Id: Ic20e08e1bfc5bc11227d907b27cd2720a5852026
Closes-Bug: #1456064
(cherry picked from commit fc9ceeed8155a7dad5fce978525ba337c753161d)

commit_message:
Fix validation failure for TemplateResource

When None is returned from `get_attr`, creating a list property
of TemplateResource with it fails during validation. This
sanitizes the None values to empty strings.

Change-Id: I3f1b50854a23cdb3fa16ac976e81aef1473c21eb
Closes-Bug: #1488475

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-20 21:30:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/597a370bd1802ff3786749d99faf9ab084cea718', 'message': 'Scheduler changes for consistency groups

This patch implements the scheduler changes for
scheduling the creation of consistency groups,
shares within consistency groups, and cgsnapshots.

The consistency group scheduling filter was added
to allow the filtering of hosts that are not supported
by a specified consistency group. If no CG is specified
on share create then this filter is a no-op. CGs will be
scheduled only to a backend that supports all of its
specified share types.

Partially implements bp manila-consistency-groups

commit_message:
Scheduler changes for consistency groups

This patch implements the scheduler changes for
scheduling the creation of consistency groups,
shares within consistency groups, and cgsnapshots.

The consistency group scheduling filter was added
to allow the filtering of hosts that are not supported
by a specified consistency group. If no CG is specified
on share create then this filter is a no-op. CGs will be
scheduled only to a backend that supports all of its
specified share types.

Partially implements bp manila-consistency-groups

Change-Id: Ia03191085cefb47a17ce99ad3f30ba70412f5802

commit_message:
Add Consistency Groups API

This patch adds the /consistency-groups and /cgsnapshots
endpoints as well as AdminActions for both.

Partially implements bp manila-consistency-groups

APIImpact

Change-Id: I5fd0d3341766fdba4d92f4a43c3d1186e7a4b38e

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import copy import datetime import uuid import mock from oslo_config import cfg import six import webob import manila.api.v1.cgsnapshots as cgs from manila.common import constants from manila import exception from manila import test from manila.tests.api import fakes CONF = cfg.CONF class CGSnapshotApiTest(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(CGSnapshotApiTest, self).setUp() self.controller = cgs.CGSnapshotController() def _get_fake_cgsnapshot(self, **values): snap = { 'id': 'fake_id', 'user_id': 'fakeuser', 'project_id': 'fakeproject', 'status': constants.STATUS_CREATING, 'name': None, 'description': None, 'consistency_group_id': None, 'created_at': datetime.datetime(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1), } snap.update(**values) expected_snap = copy.deepcopy(snap) del expected_snap['user_id'] expected_snap['links'] = mock.ANY return snap, expected_snap def _get_fake_simple_cgsnapshot(self, **values): snap = { 'id': 'fake_id', 'name': None, } snap.update(**values) expected_snap = copy.deepcopy(snap) expected_snap['links'] = mock.ANY return snap, expected_snap def _get_fake_cgsnapshot_member(self, **values): member = { 'id': 'fake_id', 'user_id': 'fakeuser', 'project_id': 'fakeproject', 'status': constants.STATUS_CREATING, 'cgsnapshot_id': None, 'share_proto': None, 'share_type_id': None, 'share_id': None, 'size': None, 'created_at': datetime.datetime(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1), } member.update(**values) expected_member = copy.deepcopy(member) del expected_member['user_id'] del expected_member['status'] expected_member['share_protocol'] = member['share_proto'] del expected_member['share_proto'] return member, expected_member def test_create_invalid_body(self): body = {"not_cg_snapshot": {}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.create, req, body) def test_create_no_consistency_group_id(self): body = {"cgnapshot": {}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.create, req, body) def test_create(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot() fake_id = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'create_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(return_value=fake_snap)) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"consistency_group_id": fake_id}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') context = req.environ['manila.context'] res_dict = self.controller.create(req, body) self.controller.cg_api.create_cgsnapshot.assert_called_once_with( context, consistency_group_id=fake_id) self.assertEqual(expected_snap, res_dict['cgsnapshot']) def test_create_cg_does_not_exist(self): fake_id = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'create_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock( side_effect=exception.ConsistencyGroupNotFound( consistency_group_id=six.text_type( uuid.uuid4()) ))) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"consistency_group_id": fake_id}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.create, req, body) def test_create_cg_does_not_a_uuid(self): self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'create_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock( side_effect=exception.ConsistencyGroupNotFound( consistency_group_id='not_a_uuid' ))) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"consistency_group_id": "not_a_uuid"}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.create, req, body) def test_create_invalid_cg(self): fake_id = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'create_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock( side_effect=exception.InvalidConsistencyGroup( reason='bad_status' ))) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"consistency_group_id": fake_id}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPConflict, self.controller.create, req, body) def test_create_with_name(self): fake_name = 'fake_name' fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot(name=fake_name) fake_id = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'create_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(return_value=fake_snap)) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"consistency_group_id": fake_id, "name": fake_name}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') context = req.environ['manila.context'] res_dict = self.controller.create(req, body) self.controller.cg_api.create_cgsnapshot.assert_called_once_with( context, consistency_group_id=fake_id, name=fake_name) self.assertEqual(expected_snap, res_dict['cgsnapshot']) def test_create_with_description(self): fake_description = 'fake_description' fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot( description=fake_description) fake_id = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'create_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(return_value=fake_snap)) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"consistency_group_id": fake_id, "description": fake_description}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') context = req.environ['manila.context'] res_dict = self.controller.create(req, body) self.controller.cg_api.create_cgsnapshot.assert_called_once_with( context, consistency_group_id=fake_id, description=fake_description) self.assertEqual(expected_snap, res_dict['cgsnapshot']) def test_create_with_name_and_description(self): fake_name = 'fake_name' fake_description = 'fake_description' fake_id = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot( description=fake_description, name=fake_name) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'create_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(return_value=fake_snap)) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"consistency_group_id": fake_id, "description": fake_description, "name": fake_name}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') context = req.environ['manila.context'] res_dict = self.controller.create(req, body) res_dict['cgsnapshot']) def test_update_with_name_and_description(self): fake_name = 'fake_name' fake_description = 'fake_description' fake_id = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot( description=fake_description, name=fake_name) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(return_value=fake_snap)) self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'update_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(return_value=fake_snap)) body = {"cgsnapshot": {"description": fake_description, "name": fake_name}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') context = req.environ['manila.context'] res_dict = self.controller.update(req, fake_id, body) self.controller.cg_api.update_cgsnapshot.assert_called_once_with( context, fake_snap, dict(name=fake_name, description=fake_description)) self.assertEqual(expected_snap, res_dict['cgsnapshot']) def test_update_snapshot_not_found(self): body = {"cgsnapshot": {}} self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(side_effect=exception.NotFound)) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound, self.controller.update, req, 'fake_id', body) def test_update_invalid_body(self): body = {"not_cgsnapshot": {}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.update, req, 'fake_id', body) def test_update_invalid_body_invalid_field(self): body = {"cgsnapshot": {"unknown_field": ""}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') exc = self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.update, req, 'fake_id', body) self.assertTrue('unknown_field' in six.text_type(exc)) def test_update_invalid_body_readonly_field(self): body = {"cgsnapshot": {"created_at": []}} req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') exc = self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.update, req, 'fake_id', body) self.assertTrue('created_at' in six.text_type(exc)) def test_list_index(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_simple_cgsnapshot() self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_all_cgsnapshots', mock.Mock(return_value=[fake_snap])) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') res_dict = self.controller.index(req) self.assertEqual([expected_snap], res_dict['cgsnapshots']) def test_list_index_no_cgs(self): self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_all_cgsnapshots', mock.Mock(return_value=[])) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') res_dict = self.controller.index(req) self.assertEqual([], res_dict['cgsnapshots']) def test_list_index_with_limit(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = mock.Mock(return_value=[fake_snap, fake_snap2])) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots?limit=1') res_dict = self.controller.index(req) self.assertEqual(1, len(res_dict['cgsnapshots'])) fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots?limit=1&offset=1') res_dict = self.controller.index(req) self.assertEqual(1, len(res_dict['cgsnapshots'])) self.assertEqual([expected_snap2], res_dict['cgsnapshots']) def test_list_detail(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot() self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_all_cgsnapshots', test_list_detail_with_limit_and_offset(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot() fake_snap2, expected_snap2 = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot( id="fake_id2") fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') res = self.controller.delete(req, fake_snap['id']) self.assertEqual(202, res.status_code) def test_delete_not_found(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot() self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(side_effect=exception.NotFound)) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound, self.controller.delete, req, fake_snap['id']) def test_delete_in_conflicting_status(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot() test_show(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot() self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(return_value=fake_snap)) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') res_dict = self.controller.show(req, fake_snap['id']) self.assertEqual(expected_snap, res_dict['cgsnapshot']) def test_show_cg_not_found(self): fake_snap, expected_snap = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot() self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_cgsnapshot', mock.Mock(side_effect=exception.NotFound)) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots') self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound, self.controller.show, req, fake_snap['id']) def test_members_empty(self): self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_all_cgsnapshot_members', mock.Mock(return_value=[])) req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank('/cgsnapshots/fake_id/members') res_dict = self.controller.members(req, 'fake_cg_id') self.assertEqual([], res_dict['cgsnapshot_members']) def test_members(self): fake_member, expected_member = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot_member() self.mock_object(self.controller.cg_api, 'get_all_cgsnapshot_members', mock.Mock(return_value=[fake_member])) req test_members_with_limit(self): fake_member, expected_member = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot_member() fake_member2, expected_member2 = self._get_fake_cgsnapshot_member( id="fake_id2") len(res_dict['cgsnapshot_members'])) self.assertEqual([expected_member2], res_dict['cgsnapshot_members'])

commit_message:
Better message on allowed address pairs error

Neutron was throwing a 500 error when a non-iterable was passed
into allowed address pairs. This patch just catches that and
converts it into a regular badrequest message.

Closes-Bug: #1477829
Change-Id: I3c6f55df4912c7a9480fa097988f910b254572fd
Signed-off-by: Kevin Benton <blak111@gmail.com>

deleted_lines: if len(address_pairs) > cfg.CONF.max_allowed_address_pair: raise AllowedAddressPairExhausted( quota=cfg.CONF.max_allowed_address_pair)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-06 11:06:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/782ec7b4f6743d71b533f4a8fdeb63602392aa39', 'message': "Reflect provider change in puppet-openstacklib

With the creation of the new openstack_config provider, some processing
that was done in nova_config has been centralized in
openstack_config.

Impacted methods are :

  * section
  * setting
  * separator

Also, this commit adds the fact that, when passing a specific string
(ensure_absent_val) the provider will behave as if ensure => absent was
specified. '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' is the default value for
ensure_absent_val.

The use case is the following :

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => 'bar' } # will work as usual

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' } # will mean absent

That means that all the current :

if $myvar {
  nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }
} else {
  nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : ensure => absent }
}

can be removed in favor of :

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }

If for any reason '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' turns out to be a valid value for
a specific parameter. One could by pass that doing the following :

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>',
ensure_absent_val => 'foo' }

Change-Id: I7ba9bf6c07edd7248e401ef5f55abf6e3464a0a3
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-06 11:27:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/f522435f2547ffa5e48a0a985c5b2a54ab88f33c', 'message': "Reflect provider change in puppet-openstacklib

commit_message:
Reflect provider change in puppet-openstacklib

With the creation of the new openstack_config provider, some processing
that was done in nova_config has been centralized in
openstack_config.

Impacted methods are :

  * section
  * setting
  * separator

Also, this commit adds the fact that, when passing a specific string
(ensure_absent_val) the provider will behave as if ensure => absent was
specified. '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' is the default value for
ensure_absent_val.

The use case is the following :

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => 'bar' } # will work as usual

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' } # will mean absent

That means that all the current :

if $myvar {
  nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }
} else {
  nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : ensure => absent }
}

can be removed in favor of :

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }

If for any reason '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' turns out to be a valid value for
a specific parameter. One could by pass that doing the following :

nova_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>',
ensure_absent_val => 'foo' }

Change-Id: I7ba9bf6c07edd7248e401ef5f55abf6e3464a0a3
Depends-On: I0eeebde3aac2662cc7e69bfad7f8d2481463a218
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/76/209876/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: desc 'Section/setting name to manage from nova.conf' newparam(:ensure_absent_val) do desc 'A value that is specified as the value property will behave as if ensure => absent was specified' defaultto('<SERVICE DEFAULT>') end

commit_message:
acceptance: bump trusty packaging to trusty-proposed/liberty

Since our recent discussion about Ubuntu packaging, we decided to bump
Ubuntu packaging to trusty-proposed/liberty so we can install Liberty in
a better shape than current situation (Staging repo).

This patch installs UCA liberty repository.

Depends-On: I57e2ddc5d0e228142f8045623ffbde362c0e7f7b
Change-Id: I9afa788c8642fd07c5cf04a42ba4697d343b6eaf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/44/219844/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class { '::openstack_extras::repo::debian::ubuntu': release => 'liberty', repo => 'proposed', package_require => true, }
deleted_lines: apt::ppa { 'ppa:ubuntu-cloud-archive/liberty-staging': # it's false by default in 2.x series but true in 1.8.x package_manage => false, } Exec['apt_update'] -> Package<||>

commit_message:
Fix incomplete error message of quota exceeded

When we boot and resize instance, if multiple requested
resource(core, ram and instances) exceeded quota,
only the detail of core resource will been outputed to
user in the exception, the loss of core and instances number
will make end user have no idea which flavor can be
used to boot instance successfully.

Fix this issue and update related test cases.

Change-Id: I969d73e2f222278ea8a2bb4c21474c13ab213d81
Closes-Bug: #1469942
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/60/197460/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: num_instances = (str(min_count) if min_count == max_count else "%s-%s" % (min_count, max_count)) requested = dict(instances=num_instances, cores=req_cores, ram=req_ram) reqs = [] useds = [] total_alloweds = [] resources = [] for resource in overs: reqs.append(str(requested[resource])) useds.append(str(quotas[resource] - headroom[resource])) total_alloweds.append(str(quotas[resource])) resources.append(resource) (overs, reqs, useds, total_alloweds, resources) = map(','.join, ( overs, reqs, useds, total_alloweds, resources)) req=reqs, used=useds, allowed=total_alloweds, resource=resources) reqs = [] useds = [] total_alloweds = [] resources = [] for resource in overs: reqs.append(str(deltas[resource])) useds.append(str(quotas[resource] - headroom[resource])) total_alloweds.append(str(quotas[resource])) resources.append(resource) (overs, reqs, useds, total_alloweds, resources) = map(','.join, (overs, reqs, useds, total_alloweds, resources)) req=reqs, used=useds, allowed=total_alloweds, resource=resources)
deleted_lines: resource = overs[0] used = quotas[resource] - headroom[resource] total_allowed = quotas[resource] overs = ','.join(overs) num_instances = (str(min_count) if min_count == max_count else "%s-%s" % (min_count, max_count)) requested = dict(instances=num_instances, cores=req_cores, ram=req_ram) req=requested[resource], used=used, allowed=total_allowed, resource=resource) resource = overs[0] used = quotas[resource] - headroom[resource] total_allowed = used + headroom[resource] overs = ','.join(overs) req=deltas[resource], used=used, allowed=total_allowed, resource=resource)

commit_message:
Add DB changes for consistency-groups

This patch adds the database migrations and db api changes
needed for the consistency groups feature.

Partially implements bp manila-consistency-groups

Change-Id: Id6fe4b77f0d31c3f0ade595b11d413cc6ac5f4c2

"""Add source_cgsnapshot_member_id to shares table This column represents the cgsnapshot_member a share was created from if it was created when creating consistency group from a cgsnapshot. Revision ID: 2644362b48ea Revises: 10d0d5198205 Create Date: 2015-07-29 19:24:48.205925 """ # revision identifiers, used by Alembic. revision = '2644362b48ea' down_revision = '10d0d5198205' from alembic import op import sqlalchemy as sa def upgrade(): op.add_column('shares', sa.Column('source_cgsnapshot_member_id', sa.String(36))) def downgrade(): op.drop_column('shares', 'source_cgsnapshot_member_id')

commit_message:
Revert "Convert identity defaults to keystone v3 api"

This change have broke the Ironic tests. Reverting to unblock the Ironic
gate.

This reverts commit 4b115ad526df7e12bbdc71e0280b3c691e53ed04.

Closes-Bug: #1492216
Change-Id: I03acfdf47caf435cede1df08fd79b288a6662435

commit_message:
Initial msync run for all Puppet OpenStack modules

This patch is the initial modulesync run, it impacts:

* gitignore: just a sync between projects
* gemfile:
  - update and allow to setup facter version and gem source
  - split beaker gems with a dedicated group
  - switch to rspec-puppet 2.2.0
* rakefile:
  - use the new syntax for lint configuration
  - add a acceptance target
* acceptance:
  - sync nodesets
* spec: added rspec coverage report

Change-Id: Ibc1c4cd5f4d9b553b565c2625b7fc380a509edc8

commit_message:
Remove race condition in test_claim_lifecycle

THe age returned by claims can differ between 2 asserts, so let's make
sure we don't uselessly check it.

Change-Id: Ide47526290bce36d939bd8a26e3bc320dc32c9fa
Closes-Bug: #1477564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/21/220521/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for msg1, msg2 in zip(messages, messages2): self.assertEqual(msg1['body'], msg2['body']) self.assertEqual(msg1['claim_id'], msg2['claim_id']) self.assertEqual(msg1['id'], msg2['id']) self.assertEqual(msg1['ttl'], msg2['ttl'])

commit_message:
glusterfs: directory mapped share layout

The directory mapped layout has been isolated from
glusterfs driver's management logic, and captured
in a layout class.

This enables the glusterfs driver to work with
several layouts -- as of the time of writing this,
with both layouts implemented so far:
-  directory mapped layout (the old way, also the
   default);
-  volume mapped layout.

Partially implements bp modular-glusterfs-share-layouts

Change-Id: I832f8ee3defcb9b76b3e7db0e1ce64a52abe09b7

commit_message:
Fix Pure create volume from cgsnapshot

We would previously lookup the consistency group id through the snapshot
db object, but with the new versioned snapshot object we can no longer
take that shortcut. We will now query the FlashArray for all Protection
Group snapshots and search for one with the cgsnapshot id in its name.

Closes-Bug: #1483916
Change-Id: Icb4991ec419c2cf46c760fa750e9f1be1528364c

commit_message:
Add info to debug test_keepalived_respawns gate failure

Current theory is that there's a bug in external_process.active,
it returns True when it shouldn't, then kill -15 on the process
pid fails because the process isn't up. Added ps -p output to
see if the process is up or not.

Change-Id: Ic062be829d5f05a1294f6b2fa54820422871ffcb
Related-Bug: #1490043

commit_message:
Correct usage of assertEqual for boolean values

There are several cases where unit tests are calling
assertEqual([True|False]) instead of the corresponding
assertTrue|assertFalse.

Pretty minor thing, but this patch corrects them to the
more correct calls.

Could add hacking check, but that seems overkill for
something like this.

Change-Id: I1de629ed9e9770157be47f4b1b0ada8388029072

commit_message:
Import not found for glance

Glance now depends on python-castellan and python-cryptography but
the package is not in the package depends list.

Change-Id: I8ba8c191572b0c7f51df5948a2951d9a7e0aead4
Closes-Bug: #1492641

subject: Permit larger database connection count
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-06 11:13:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/9c2a3669df4c45f8eea40b2cae09a7a4665367a5', 'message': 'Permit larger database connection count

The default incoming database connection count is limited to 151
connections and outgoing from openstack services are limited to 10
connections.  These are not sufficient in a 100 node 3 controller
deployment to launch several heat stacks simulatenously.

Data measured on bare metal shows that 250 connections are needed
to launch one 25 VM heat stack with 3 controller nodes with 209
tasks (default enablement).

Change-Id: If60b540010d6d173a393fa91fa30cb3ba572cfc0
Closes-Bug: #1492719

The default incoming database connection count is limited to 151
connections.  These are not sufficient in a 100 node 3 controller
deployment to launch several heat stacks simulatenously.

Data measured on bare metal shows that 250 connections are needed
to launch one 25 VM heat stack with 3 controller nodes with 209
tasks (default enablement).

Change-Id: If60b540010d6d173a393fa91fa30cb3ba572cfc0
Closes-Bug: #1492719
'}]
commit_message:
Permit larger database connection count

The default incoming database connection count is limited to 151
connections.  These are not sufficient in a 100 node 3 controller
deployment to launch several heat stacks simulatenously.

Data measured on bare metal shows that 250 connections are needed
to launch one 25 VM heat stack with 3 controller nodes with 209
tasks (default enablement).

Change-Id: If60b540010d6d173a393fa91fa30cb3ba572cfc0
Closes-Bug: #1492719
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/05/220805/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: max_connections=1000

commit_message:
Remove ansible-lint-jobs from infra-ansible gate and enable experimental job

Currently ansible-lint-jobs does not work with
the infra-ansible repo, that job is only meant
for ansible roles.

This patch removes ansible-lint-jobs from the check
and gate queue for infra-ansible and set noops to
allow merges.
It also introduces the gate-infra-ansible job on
the experimental queue for testing, would enable
that on check/gate when we get confidence on it.

Change-Id: I8b6871d24e79817685e1ca2b21d4334ac9ad5e39

commit_message:
event-alarm: fix the order of alarms in unit test

'test_continue_following_evaluation_after_exception' might be faild.
It depends on the order of alarms which sorted by id. So this patch
fixs the alarm order by setting ids explicitly.

Change-Id: I6842ee31ad98ba86e5181abbe0075313c4a69496

commit_message:
event-alarm: delete debug message to show # of alarms

This patch delete the debug log mssage to show the number of alarms
found at the beginning of event evaluation. Developer still can see
those alarms in the log messages generated in each alarm evaluation.

The alarm storage api returns generator, so it should be safe that
we don't touch the returned value.

Change-Id: I6d61be5ab8ae2ee53a1528477a5686a5e7fa33d6
Closes-Bug: #1492098

Create job for infra ansible

I can't just use the ansible roles job template, since this project
contains playbooks and roles, I will put in-repo script to run tests
and call it from CI job.

commit_message:
Add OS::Sahara::DataSource resource

blueprint sahara-edp

Change-Id: Ie9b0ae5e396b37f5aff286fb94c12b9e15bf4198
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/40/210040/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from heat.common.i18n import _ from heat.engine import constraints from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import resource from heat.engine import support class DataSource(resource.Resource): support_status = support.SupportStatus(version='5.0.0') PROPERTIES = ( NAME, TYPE, URL, DESCRIPTION, USER, PASSWORD ) = ( 'name', 'type', 'url', 'description', 'user', 'password' ) properties_schema = { NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _("Name of the data source.") ), TYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Type of the data source.'), constraints=[ constraints.AllowedValues(['swift', 'hdfs', 'maprfs']), ], required=True ), URL: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('URL for the data source.'), required=True ), DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Description of the data source.'), default='' ), USER: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Username for accessing the data source URL.') ), PASSWORD: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _("Password for accessing the data source URL.") ), } default_client_name = 'sahara' entity = 'data_sources' def _data_source_name(self): return self.properties[self.NAME] or self.physical_resource_name() def handle_create(self): args = { 'name': self._data_source_name(), 'description': self.properties[self.DESCRIPTION], 'data_source_type': self.properties[self.TYPE], 'url': self.properties[self.URL], 'credential_user': self.properties[self.USER], 'credential_pass': self.properties[self.PASSWORD] } data_source = self.client().data_sources.create(**args) self.resource_id_set(data_source.id) def handle_delete(self): if not self.resource_id: return try: self.client().data_sources.delete(self.resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) # TODO(tlashchova): remove this method when bug #1479003 is fixed. def _show_resource(self): ds = self.client().data_sources.get(self.resource_id) return ds._info def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Sahara::DataSource': DataSource, }

commit_message:
Support use_autoconfig in sahara clusters

Since 0.10.0 python-saharaclient has ability to specify
use_autoconfig parameter when creating clusters.
This patch adds support for this feature to
OS::Sahara::Cluster resource in Heat.

Change-Id: I91c039d95db6702ffed3a156aaa296e54305ef4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/14/219614/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: USE_AUTOCONFIG 'use_autoconfig' USE_AUTOCONFIG: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.BOOLEAN, _("Configure most important configs automatically."), support_status=support.SupportStatus(version='5.0.0') ) use_autoconfig = self.properties[self.USE_AUTOCONFIG] net_id=net_id, use_autoconfig=use_autoconfig)

commit_message:
Enable to update external network subnet's gateway-ip

This patch enables users to update gateway_ip of a subnet even if
the subnet is in use for an external network of a router.

Change-Id: I78d2b024c99b1af0001bd454465d2fc02692cbf2
Closes-Bug: #1317363
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/39/194939/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _check_subnet_in_use_for_router_external(self, context, subnet): l3plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( service_constants.L3_ROUTER_NAT) if l3plugin: gw_ports = self._get_router_gw_ports_by_network(context, subnet['network_id']) if gw_ports: reason = _("Gateway can't be changed since the subnet is " "in use for an external network of a router.") raise n_exc.SubnetInUse(subnet_id=subnet['id'], reason=reason) self._check_subnet_in_use_for_router_external(context, db_subnet)

commit_message:
Make Neutron service flavor save service_type

While the service_type exists in the resource attributes and as
a database field for a Flavor, the creation dictionary did not
pass the value so the service_type was not being persisted
in the database nor returned.

Enhanced unit test to show problem.  Test fails on old code
to save or return the input service_type.

Change-Id: I4dba287f5972ecebd193d65e7f542dd0a65f055b
Closes-Bug: 1490063
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/34/218534/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertEqual(constants.LOADBALANCER, res[0]['service_type'])

subject: glusterfs: volume mapped share layout
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-20 14:58:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/2a70d83f052973403db348dd32f12e7e4840463b', 'message': "glusterfs: separate native's management logic into volume mapped layout

The volume management done by gluster_native exists
now as a separate layout class. gluster_native
implements by itself only {allow,deny}_access,
for the rest it uses the layout code.

Semantics is preserved with one difference:
the Manila host now is assumed to be set up so that
it can mount the GlusterFS volumes without any
complications. Earlier we assumed to not have cert
based access from Manila host, and turned therefore
SSL off and on on the GlusterFS side. This does not
make sense for the separate, layout-agnostic logic.
(Nb. we already wanted to make the move to set this
assumption, regardless of the layout work.)

Partially implements bp modular-glusterfs-share-layouts

Change-Id: I3cbc55eed0f61fe4808873f78811b6c3fd1c66aa
